title: 103_hr252
content: The "Cabinet-Level Interagency Task Force on Welfare Reform Act of 1993" establishes a task force to coordinate and reform Federal programs assisting individuals with limited incomes to achieve self-sufficiency. The task force is known as the "Cabinet-Level Interagency Task Force on Welfare Reform" and is responsible for developing a comprehensive legislative proposal. The Task Force will review and coordinate Federal programs assisting individuals with limited incomes. It will develop a legislative proposal to reform these programs by providing assistance according to a coordinated plan, establishing flexible eligibility standards, and creating a single application process for assistance. The Task Force will review and coordinate Federal programs for individuals with limited incomes, aiming for self-sufficiency and independence. A report with a legislative proposal must be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Task Force consists of 6 members appointed for life, including Secretaries of Agriculture, Education, Health and Human Services, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, and Treasury. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. The Task Force elects a chairperson and meets as needed. The Task Force, consisting of 6 members appointed for life, including Secretaries of Agriculture, Education, Health and Human Services, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, and Treasury, meets at the call of the chairperson. A majority of members is required for a quorum. The Task Force will have a director appointed by the chairperson, who can request personnel from Federal agencies to assist on a reimbursable basis. The director and staff can be appointed without following certain civil service laws, but their pay cannot exceed the maximum for GS-13 of the General Schedule. The Task Force, under the chairperson's authority, can obtain official data from Federal agencies, use the United States mails, receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services, and contract with government and private agencies for research and services. The Task Force can conduct research, surveys, and other necessary services to fulfill its duties. The Task Force will terminate 3 months after the report is submitted to Congress.
